mn77:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

mn77:3.9: Then the Buddha went to the monastery of the wanderers.

mn77:10.4: Once it happened that he was teaching an assembly of many hundreds.

mn77:10.6: And one of their spiritual companions nudged them with their knee, to indicate:
mn77:10.7: “Hush, venerable, don’t make sound! Our teacher, the Blessed One, is teaching!”
mn77:10.8: While the ascetic Gotama is teaching an assembly of many hundreds, there is no sound of his disciples coughing or clearing their throats.
mn77:10.9: That large crowd is poised on the edge of their seats, thinking:
mn77:10.10: “Whatever the Buddha teaches, we shall listen to it.”
mn77:10.11: It’s like when there’s a person at the crossroads pressing out pure wild honey,
mn77:10.12: and a large crowd is poised on the edge of their seats.
mn77:10.13: In the same way, while the ascetic Gotama is teaching an assembly of many hundreds, there is no sound of his disciples coughing or clearing their throats.

mn77:10.16: Even when a disciple of the ascetic Gotama abandons the training and returns to a lesser life, having been overly attached to their spiritual companions, they speak only praise of the teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha. mn77:10.17: They become monastery workers or lay followers and keep the five precepts.
mn77:10.18: That’s how the ascetic Gotama is honored, respected, revered, and worshiped by his disciples. And that’s how his disciples, honoring and respecting him, remain loyal to him.’”

mn77:19.1: Suppose my disciples are loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of robe. Well, there are disciples of mine who have rag robes, wearing shabby robes. They gather scraps from charnel ground, rubbish dumps, and shops, make them into a patchwork robe and wear it.
mn77:19.2: But sometimes I wear robes offered by householders that are strong, yet next to which bottle-gourd down is coarse.
mn77:19.3: So if it was the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of robe, then those disciples who wear rag robes would not be loyal to me.
mn77:20.1: Suppose my disciples are loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of alms-food. mn77:20.2: But sometimes I even eat by invitation boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out, served with many soups and sauces.
mn77:20.3: So if it was the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of alms-food, then those disciples who eat only alms-food would not be loyal to me.
mn77:21.1: Suppose my disciples are loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of lodging. Well, there are disciples of mine who stay at the root of a tree, in the open air. For eight months they don’t go under a roof.
mn77:21.2: But sometimes I even stay in bungalows, plastered inside and out, draft-free, with latches fastened and windows shuttered.
mn77:21.3: So if it was the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of lodging, then those disciples who stay at the root of a tree would not be loyal to me.

mn77:38.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the eight liberations.

mn77:48.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the four absorptions.
mn77:48.2: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn77:49.4: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of samādhi. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.

mn77:52.7: ‘This gem of lapus lazuli is naturally beautiful, eight-faceted, with expert workmanship, transparent and clear, possessing all good qualities.
mn77:52.8: And it’s strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown.’
mn77:52.9: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to understand this:
mn77:52.10: ‘This body consists of form. It’s made up of the four elements, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.
mn77:52.11: And this consciousness of mine is attached to it, tied to it.’
mn77:52.12: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
mn77:53.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to create from this body another body, consisting of form, mind-made, complete in all its various parts, not deficient in any faculty.
mn77:53.2: Suppose a person was to draw a reed out from its sheath.
mn77:53.4: ‘This is the reed, this is the sheath.
mn77:53.5: The reed and the sheath are different things.
mn77:53.6: The reed has been drawn out from the sheath.’
mn77:53.7: Or suppose a person was to draw a sword out from its scabbard.
mn77:53.9: ‘This is the sword, this is the scabbard.
mn77:53.10: The sword and the scabbard are different things.
mn77:53.11: The sword has been drawn out from the scabbard.’
mn77:53.12: Or suppose a person was to draw a snake out from its slough.
mn77:53.14: ‘This is the snake, this is the slough.
mn77:53.15: The snake and the slough are different things.
mn77:53.16: The snake has been drawn out from the slough.’
mn77:53.17: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to create from this body another body, consisting of form, mind-made, complete in all its various parts, not deficient in any faculty.
mn77:53.18: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
mn77:54.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to wield the many kinds of psychic power:
mn77:54.2: multiplying themselves and becoming one again;
mn77:54.4: going unimpeded through a wall, an embankment, or a mountain as if through space;
mn77:54.5: diving in and out of the earth as if it was water;
mn77:54.6: walking on water as if it was earth;
mn77:54.7: flying cross-legged through the air like a bird;
mn77:54.8: touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful. They control the body as far as the Brahmā realm.
mn77:54.9: Suppose there an expert potter or their apprentice had some well-prepared clay. They could produce any kind of pot that they like.
mn77:54.10: Or suppose there an expert ivory-carver or their apprentice had some well-prepared ivory. They could produce any kind of ivory item that they like.
mn77:54.11: Or suppose there an expert goldsmith or their apprentice had some well-prepared gold. They could produce any kind of gold item that they like.
mn77:54.12: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to wield the many kinds of psychic power …
mn77:54.20: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
mn77:55.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use so that, with clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds,
mn77:55.2: human and divine, whether near or far.
mn77:55.3: Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four directions.
mn77:55.4: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use so that, with clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds,
mn77:55.5: human and divine, whether near or far.
mn77:55.6: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
mn77:56.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with their own mind.
mn77:56.2: They understand mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’, and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed’;
mn77:56.3: mind with hate as ‘mind with hate’, and mind without hate as ‘mind without hate’;
mn77:56.4: mind with delusion as ‘mind with delusion’, and mind without delusion as ‘mind without delusion’;
mn77:56.5: contracted mind as ‘contracted mind’, and scattered mind as ‘scattered mind’;
mn77:56.6: expansive mind as ‘expansive mind’, and unexpansive mind as ‘unexpansive mind’;
mn77:56.7: mind that is not supreme as ‘mind that is not supreme’, and mind that is supreme as ‘mind that is supreme’;
mn77:56.8: mind unified in samādhi as ‘mind unified in samādhi’, and mind not unified in samādhi as ‘mind not unified in samādhi’;
mn77:56.9: freed mind as ‘freed mind’, and unfreed mind as ‘unfreed mind’.
mn77:56.10: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they examine their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they had a spot they’d know ‘I have a spot’, and if they had no spots they’d know ‘I have no spots’.
mn77:56.11: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with their own mind …
mn77:56.28: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
mn77:57.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to recollect the many kinds of past lives, that is,
mn77:57.2: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand lives; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world evolving, many eons of the world contracting and evolving.
mn77:57.3: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else.
mn77:57.4: There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’
mn77:57.5: And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
mn77:57.6: Suppose a person was to leave their home village and go to another village. From that village they’d go to yet another village. And from that village they’d return to their home village.
mn77:57.9: ‘I went from my home village to another village. There I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that.
mn77:57.10: From that village I went to yet another village. There too I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. And from that village I returned to my home village.’
mn77:57.11: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to recollect the many kinds of past lives …
mn77:57.15: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
mn77:58.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use so that, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds:
mn77:58.2: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
mn77:58.3: These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’
mn77:58.4: And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
mn77:58.5: Suppose there were two houses with doors.
mn77:58.6: A person with good eyesight standing in between them would see people entering and leaving a house and wandering to and fro.
mn77:58.7: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use so that, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn …
mn77:58.9: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
mn77:59.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having achieved it with their own insight due to the end of defilements.
mn77:59.2: Suppose there was a lake that was transparent, clear, and unclouded. A person with good eyesight standing on the bank would see the mussel shells, gravel and pebbles, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.
mn77:59.4: ‘This lake is transparent, clear, and unclouded. And here are the mussel shells, gravel and pebbles, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.’
mn77:59.5: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having achieved it with their own insight due to the end of defilements.
mn77:59.6: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
mn77:59.7: This is the fifth quality because of which my disciples are loyal to me.
mn77:60.1: These are the five qualities because of which my disciples honor, respect, revere, and worship me; and after honoring and respecting me, they remain loyal to me.”
mn77:61.1: This is what the Buddha said.
mn77:61.2: Uplifted, the wanderer Sakuludāyī approved of what the Buddha said.
